page.title: 12CEMETERIES
page.content: Efford Cemetery is one of the two main cemeteries in Plymouth, maintained by the City Council. There are 13,500 grave spaces, but there have already been 28,750 burials there since it was opened. This means that each grave space has been used at least twice. There are about 200 burials annually. Most people are cremated when they die and there are about 1,500 cremations annually. People prefer cremations because it does not use up a lot of ground, and the ashes of relatives can be saved in a special urn. There are two memorials in the cemetery - one to the civilians killed in the 2nd World War, and the other to the members of the Armed Forces cremated at Efford. The oldest grave we could find dates from the middle 1800s.
